On September 8th, 1900--the anniversary's tomorrow--a hurricane hit Galveston, Texas, that until last week was considered the deadliest natural disaster in US history.
Galveston obviously still exists; the storm eternally altered the city's destiny.
Joining us now to tell us the story is Casey Greene, head of the special collections at the Rosenberg Library in Galveston, Texas.
And thanks very much for being with us today.
Well, thanks for having me.
Tell us a little bit about Galveston before the storm.
Well, first of all my sympathy is with everyone who's been affected by this horrible disaster.
Galveston was Texas' principal city and seaport in the 19th century.
The city itself was thriving economically.
We were a boom town.
But the local government was bankrupt, and at that time we had war politics.
The hurricane came September 8th, 1900, and literally the whole city and island of Galveston were inundated by floodwaters.
How many people died?
We don't know.
We estimate upwards of 8,000 on Galveston Island alone, and several thousand more on the mainland, making this, to date, the nation's deadliest natural disaster.
But Galveston did rebuild in a dramatic, total way.

And I agree with what most of your callers have said, that this offers the opportunity to do it right and to make substantial and transformational changes to the city of New Orleans and the middle Gulf Coast.
But after the storm, we all read that the city of Houston, Texas, about 50 miles away up the ship canal--Houston became the principal commercial city of Texas, and Galveston never recovered.
Well, there's a reason for that, because Galveston was recovering at a time in 1901 that the state's economy shifted from agriculture to oil.
We had the Spindletop oil boom.
Now Houston became the oil--started becoming the oil capital of the United States in the 1920s, so the change was gradual.
It didn't happen overnight.
Galveston in 1901 pioneered the commission form of local government, and Houston and a couple hundred other American cities eventually adopted it.
And this simply meant that professional businessmen were in charge of various city departments, and they operated their departments in a businesslike manner, accountable to the people of Galveston.
Now we also had some physical changes that dramatically transformed the local landscape.
First, a seawall, 17 feet high, was built to protect the city from the Gulf of Mexico between 1902 and 1904, and it was extended in later years.
And then after that, we had the elevation of the city's--it was called the grade raising.
Literally, the city was raised from an elevation about eight feet along our principal east-west thoroughfare to a height of just about 16 feet behind our seawall.
And this was called the grade raising, and it took place between 1904 and 1910, and it was extended westward in subsequent years.
And then, third, we also had the construction of a causeway that handled vehicular, foot and railroad traffic that connected Galveston and Galveston Island to the mainland of Texas.
So between 1900 and 1912, Galveston transformed itself radically in terms of its local politics and technologically as well.
And all I'd like to say is that Galveston offers an opportunity to study how one city 105 years ago changed itself in light of a terrible disaster.
And could now, ironically, be among those cities that could reap some economic benefits from the distress elsewhere.
Well, we have our share of evacuees here from New Orleans.
Of course, Texas has taken a huge share of this--of people, victims, as have other states.
I don't know about Galveston benefiting directly from this terrible disaster, but we do provide a model for studying how one city over a century ago changed itself in response to a hurricane.
